subject: Re: [junit] Including test cases with production code

messageBody:
I agree with Michael Silverstein (below).
"Customer" is so vague!
In my original post, I talked about going into "production" because that's
the type of work I do. I don't do code for "consumers" style end-users.
More like a system that is put into production at some point, not an app
installed on a desktop. Having a special hook in the app to enable running
unit tests on production hardware & software setup might prove valuable when
you suspect a problem with a JVM for example.

I totally agree with what Michael expressed below. In my case, I currently
work for an IT departement that wants to maintain the code on it's own after
the project (so "source code is provided"). They are buying code, and we
give them tests as an added bonus. As for bandwith & storage, I think it is
a moot point. How much for a 20 Gig theses days? If the code is not an
applet, I don't see why it would generate bandwith loss more than me
downloading mp3s ;)

mathieu
----- Original Message -----
From: Michael Silverstein

Definitely if source code is provided, including test cases make sense. I
think we all agree now that within the context of end-user application
deployment, it doesn't make sense to include test cases, except for special
diagnostic circumstances. If a product deliverable includes source code, or
is a framework that provides a set of Java APIs, then a set of test cases is
invaluable for documenting and validating product usage.
